comments.body: This seems like an unrelated change.  It is probably ok to sneak this in, but it sticks out here.

This was because I centralized the "create-or-update-configmap" functionality which was used in two places; here and the cluster info code. I thought it would make sense to adopt the new func in both places... but no strong opinion here

Isn't this really an overwrite?  

Could we stash somewhere, the previous one as a backup in case someone has modified the originals. 

Same applies for *.

What's the reason to upgrade system-internal manifests if we don't overwrite?
Yes, it's overwriting, but on the other hand it will be super hard to detect a change without building in earlier manifests into kubeadm.

Also, how do we know what the user wants? Do they want to keep old, modified manifests or do they really want to upgrade.

If you have a preferred location for stashing things, I'm all ears though...

If I treat package management as an analogous example, it would never explicitly overwrite without user specification so they know they are going to blast them.    

As of today, there is no ObjectMeta record on who authored/signed a resource update, if we knew that we could have a check.

Yeah, that's the problem. If that was in ObjectMeta (maybe shouldn't be, but anyway), we could easily check that.

I think this should just be a caveat in the instructions. If you have modified things kubeadm installed in the kube-system name, you must redo those mods after upgrading.

Agree so we can proceed with this?
So long as we spell it out in **bold** in the docs I'm ok.
Also update a release note on this one to denote, and lgtm from me.
I think that DaemonSets don't go through the scheduler so taints don't apply.  But this doesn't hurt.
Now they do. This changed in `v1.6.0-alpha.3`

the problem here is that we're taking a clientset and requiring an apiserver to be active.
So unless we mock something out (which is far out of scope for this PR), we unfortunately can't have unit tests for this. But we can have other tests though (like integration, but let's talk about that elsewhere)

If you take a look here:

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/client/clientset_generated/clientset/fake/clientset_generated.go

You'll see that one is mocked out.  You should be able to create a unit test doing this.

Same as above. While tests require time to implement, we should add them from now on.

On a sidenote, @dmmcquay really great to see you leading the effort and pointing people in the right direction. Keep it up!

@pires See:
> I couldn't get the fake clientset working. It seems like it is broken. We should get someone to help us to figure it out. It seems to be all there, I just couldn't get it to work.
If we keep this PR open, I'm sure it will serve as a push to have someone looking into what's happening. If we have this merged, there goes the push. We should bring this up later in SIG meeting.

@luxas I agree with @pires. After todays SIG meeting, it seems like fake.ClientSet not working will be investigated.  This PR being open and being blocked on fake.ClientSet not working will hopefully get that fixed faster.  If we allow this to go through and not add tests they won't have anything pushing to get it done.
this should take an interface, not a concrete client
